title: Chi-Squared Values and $p$-values
question_text:
A ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for homogeneity of populations was conducted using data found in a two-way table consisting of $6\text{ rows}$ and $3\text{ columns}$. The ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ value was found to be $19.63$.
What can we conclude about the results of this test?

choices.text:
Since
p
=
0.033
, we have strong evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.

Since
p
=
0.354
, we do not have enough evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.

Since
p
=
19.63
, we do not have any evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.

Since
p
<
0.05
, we have strong evidence that the populations are independent of each other.

Since
p
>
0.05
, we cannot conclude that the populations are independent of each other.
